Electromagnetic Linear Stage for cryogenic environment

@ The invention concerns an electromagnetically driven linear stage, specially designed for use in a cryogenic environment. Due to this approach, a fully contactless drive concept without any friction can be realized to create movement. Special attention has been made to cope with the differences in thermal expansion while cooling down to a few Kelvin. Also, dissipation has been minimized by keeping the electromagnetic coils in a temperature range of low resistance by cooling them and monitoring their resistance and temperature. An actively controlled element, which creates a friction-based locking between the moving table and the base frame, has been introduced as an option to cancel out any dissipation in the coils when the desired end position is reached. Present commercially available positioning systems in cryogenic environments are based on slip-stick drives with piezo actuators, These positioning systems have a few drawbacks: 1}Sinee their concept is based on alternatively and stick, wear will occur in the slippage phase which will fead to limited lifetime and lack of reliability. 2) The speed of piezo driven stick-slip actuators is practically limited to about | mm/s which leads te ed long repositioning times of about 10 seconds fora typical 10 mm stroke. These drawbacks can be mitigated by a completely different drive concept, based on electromagnetic 39 forces, which is fully contactless without any friction involved to create movement. This electromagnetic linear motor has been combined with a guide concept to enable movements in one direction with special attention to make this electromagnetic linear stage cryogenic and vacuum compatible. Independent claim 1.

1.1 Document D1 (fig. 1-6; par. [0046]) is regarded as being the prior art closest to the subject-matter of claim 1, and discloses A magnetically conductive strip (30) provided with permanent magnets connected to a base frame (10) such that the strip is fixed to the base frame at a The base frame can be connected to a body on one side in the longitudinal direction with high stiffness and on the other side by introducing an elastic guide to this same body, so that the base frame can be fixed relative to the body in 6 degrees of freedom, but can still expand freely as a result of temperature variations without large material stresses occurring in the base frame; (a base frame can be connected to any body. This part of the claim is not limiting) Form NL237-3 (separate sheet) (July 2006) (sheet 1) The base frame is provided with two eeramie guide shafts (51) which are connected to the base frame such that the guide shafts are each fixed to the The guiding shafts provide a smooth and hard running surface for a table (20) provided with ceramic rollers (par. [0046]); The moving table is provided with electromagnetic coils (40) so that they are subjected to an electromagnetic force in the intended direction of movement of the table by current control. 1.2 The subject-matter of claim 1 therefore differs from this known D1 in that — the strip is-fixedtothe-baseframe-ate_pointethightigidity butcan expand freely as a result of temperature variations, inter alia occurring upon cooling from room temperature to cryogenic temperature, without large material stresses occurring in the magnetic strip or the base frame; — the guide shafts are-each fixedic the base frame ata point of high rigidity ‘ut can expand freely due to temperature variations without large material stresses occurring in the guide shafts or the base frame, so that the straightness of the guide shafts is maintained; — the guide shafts and the rollers are ceramic — the table is provided on one side with 4 rollers in such a configuration that when they contact one of the guide shafts, the table is fixed in 4 degrees of freedom and can not only translate in the intended direction but can also rotate about the guide shaft in contact with the 4 rollers; The table on Form NL237-3 (separate sheet) (July 2006) (sheet 2) the other side is provided with two rollers, one roller of which is fixedly connected to the table, but the other roller is connected to the table in such a way that it exerts a closing force so that all rollers remain in contact with the guide shafts, so that the table can only perform a pure translation in the intended direction; The closing force is introduced by a resilient element of low stiffness, so that differences in expansion due to temperature variations do not cause any appreciable change in the pretension of the rollers; and is therefore new. 1.3 The problem to be solved by the present invention may be regarded as how to make the electromagnetically driven linear stage suitable to operate with a very high-precision under varying temperature conditions. 1.4 The solution to this problem proposed in claim 1 of the present application is considered as involving an inventive step for the following reasons: D2 (fig. 3) discloses to avoid deformation due to thermal stress such as strain or bending by having one end rigidly fixed and by letting another end move, but this is rather on what is the equivalent of the distance between the two guide shafts. In the application, the variations between the distance are dealt with by a roller with a close force. D3 (par. [0124]) discloses the use of a loose/floating bearing to allow thermal expansion in order to couple what is the equivalent as the two guide shafts. D4 (par. [0069]) discloses a guide formed of ceramic. D5 (fig. 4) discloses the use of a closing force with a resilient element of low stiffness (spring), to avoid having to adjust the level of the different rollers. Some of the techniques used to cope with the temperature variations are well- known in the prior art. However, it does not appear to be obvious to combine them to come to the subject-matter claimed in claim 1. Especially the feature that the magnet strip can freely expand with respect to a base frame where it is attached to involves some non-obvious modifications to the prior art document D1. It is noted that D6 discloses similar features as D1.

2 Dependent claims 2-6.

Claims 2-6 are dependent on claim 1 and as such also meet the requirements of novelty and inventive step. Form NL237-3 (separate sheet) (July 2006) (sheet 3)
